author: taempark
content: I'm trying to understand what you mean by "L2s should have L1 security minus the risk of a bug in code". Can you elaborate?

author: taempark
content: Cuz I assume the security comes down to the lowest bound at the end of the day. Would love to explore if L2s can achieve higher security than the underlying layer.

author: sky.cactus
content:
If the L1 is compromised, then the L2 is also compromised.
If the L2 has a bug, then the L2 is compromised.

author: sky.cactus
content: That is for an ideal L2.

author: sky.cactus
content:
The current set of L2s are far from ideal and instead are more like:
If the L1 is compromised, then the L2 is also compromised.
If the L2 keyholders are compromised, then the L2 is compromised.
If the L2 code is compromised, then the L2 is compromised.
If the L2 governance is compromised, then the L2 is compromised.
If the L2 changes the code, any of the above could now be possible where previously they weren't possible.

author: taempark
content: Gotcha. So you mean that the security comes down to the lowest bound of all components comprising L2, and current L2 has many other weak components besides L1 security and L2 code bugs.
